questions.question: Question 1: Solid wastes generally should not contain:
questions.explanation:
Solid wastes should not contain nightsoil, which is untreated human waste (feces). Solid wastes generally contain: • Garbage (food wastes) • Rubbish waste (papers, plastics, etc.) • Demolition products (bricks, masonry, etc.) • Sewage treatment residue 614 
Sold by @itachibot • Dead animals and other waste materials

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a method of solid waste or refuse disposal?
questions.explanation: Oxidation ponds are not used for solid waste or refuse disposal. It is used for sewage treatment. Methods of solid waste disposal are: • Dumping • Controlled tipping • Incineration • Composting • Manure pits • Burial

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is the most insanitary method of waste disposal?
questions.explanation:
The most insanitary method of waste disposal is dumping. Methods of waste disposal include: • Controlled tipping or sanitary landfill - Most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where 
suitable land is available • Incineration - Method of choice where suitable land is not available • Composting • Manure pits • Burial • Dumping

questions.question: Question 4: Which method is most appropriate when suitable land for waste disposal is available?
questions.explanation:
Controlled tipping is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal when suitable land is 
available. In this method, waste materials are placed in a trench, compacted, and covered with earth at the 
end of the day. This method is also called a sanitary landfill. Chemical, bacteriological and 
physical changes occur in the buried refuse with temperatures rising to over 60 degrees Celsius 
within 7 days. Methods used for controlled tipping are: • Trench method 615 
Sold by @itachibot • Ramp method • Area method Sewage farming is also a method of sewage disposal in places where sufficient and suitable land is 
available. It is also called land treatment or broad irrigation.

questions.question:
Question 5: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a 
population of 10,000 is:
questions.explanation:
In controlled tipping, one acre of land is required by the trench method to be practiced for a 
population of 10,000. It is also known as a sanitary landfill. It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where 
suitable land is available. In this method, waste material is placed in a trench or other prepared 
area. Then, it is adequately compacted and covered with earth at the end of the day. Methods used in controlled tipping are: • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries, and clay pits

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is false about composting?

options.a: Bangalore method is an aerobic process
options.b: Mechanical composting uses a controlled environment
options.c: Nightsoil can also be disposed with composting
options.d: Compost has few or no disease-causing pathogens

questions.explanation:
The Bangalore method of composting is an anaerobic process. Composting is a method of combined disposal of refuse and nightsoil. In this process, organic 
matter is broken down into compost. It has manure value and few or no disease-causing 
pathogens. Bangalore method is an anaerobic method and is also called hot fermentation 
process. Trenches with a depth of not more than 90cm are used for this. This is done by spreading 
a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. 
Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground 
level. The heap is then covered with excavated earth. At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition 
will be completed. Mechanical composting is an aerobic process. In this method, compost is manufactured on a large 
scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. The refuse is first cleared of 
salvageable materials. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The 
pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and 
incubated.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is the oldest non-service type of latrines in India?
questions.explanation:
The oldest non-service type of latrines in India is the borehole latrine. It was introduced in the 
1930s to combat hookworm infections. Special equipment called auger is used to dig a borehole latrine. Advantages: • No special staff is needed for upkeep as after using the latrine is closed and another hole is dug 
elsewhere • Breeding of flies is less • No water pollution if located far from a water source Demerits: • Fills up rapidly • Augers are not readily available • Water pollution is still a risk 618 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A health committee formed under Swachh Bharat Mission is involved in constructing septic 
tanks in every household. Which of the following is true about a septic tank?
questions.explanation:
The recommended retention period for a septic tank is 24 hours. If the retention period is too short, there is insufficient treatment of sewage and if it is too long, 
then undue septicity results. There are single and double-chambered septic tanks. The minimum capacity recommended for a 
septic tank is 500 gallons. The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.

questions.question: Question 13: What is wastewater without human excreta called?
questions.explanation:
Wastewater that doesn’t contain human excreta is called sullage. It is also called greywater. E.g., 
waste water from the kitchen. Sewage is wastewater from a community that contains solid and liquid excreta along with street 
and yard washings. It is also called blackwater.

questions.question:
Question 14: What is the average amount of sewage which flows though the sewerage system in 24 hours 
known as?
questions.explanation:
The average amount of sewage which flows though the sewerage system in 24 hours is known as 
dry weather flow.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not used to express the strength of sewage?
questions.explanation: E. coli count is not used to express the strength of sewage. The strength of sewage is expressed only in terms of: • Biochemical oxygen demand • Chemical oxygen demand • Suspended solids

questions.question: Question 16: What does the biochemical oxygen demand of sewage indicate?
questions.explanation:
Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) indicates the organic content of sewage. 620 
Sold by @itachibot It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage for aerobic destruction by 
living microorganisms. If wastewater contains toxic substances, the organic load is measured by the chemical oxygen 
demand.

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following values of biochemical oxygen demand would indicate that the sewage 
is weak?
questions.explanation: Sewage with biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) of 100mg/L would indicate that it is weak. If the BOD is  300 mg/L, sewage is said to be strong.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not a part of the primary treatment of sewage?
questions.explanation:
Aeration tank is not a part of primary treatment of sewage. It is a part of secondary treatment of 
sewage.

questions.question: Question 19: What is the function of the grit chamber in modern sewage treatment plants?

options.d: Allow anaerobic auto-digestion of organic matter

questions.explanation:
The function of the grit chamber in modern sewage treatment plants is to allow heavier 
particles in the sewage to settle.

questions.question: Question 20: Trickling filter method is used in which of the following?
questions.explanation: The trickling filter method is used in secondary sewage treatment.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is the heart of the activated sludge process?
questions.explanation: The heart of the activated sludge process is the aeration tanks.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is not a requirement for an oxidation pond?

options.b: Culex larva lies in water with head faced downwards
options.c: Anopheles larva lies parallel to the undersurface of water

questions.explanation:
Aeration is not a requirement for an oxidation pond. Oxidation ponds are also called waste stabilization ponds or redox ponds or sewage lagoons. They 
have become a popular method of purifying sewage for small communities. It is usually an open, 
shallow pool of around 1 – 1.5m depth with an inlet and outlet. Requisites for an oxidation pond include: 621 
Sold by @itachibot • Algae • Saprophytic bacteria • Sunlight All of the above factors help in the treatment of sewage waste through aerobic and anaerobic 
processes. The effluent formed can be used for land irrigation or can be forwarded for further 
treatment. 622 
Sold by @itachibot Medical Entomology - Mosquitoes and Flies
